verses.text: This is the word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD when King Zedekiah sent to him Pashhur the son of Malchiah and Zephaniah the priest, the son of Maaseiah, saying,
verses.comment: The narrative shifts focus to Jeremiah's prophetic ministry during King Zedekiah's reign. The involvement of the priest Zephaniah highlights the intertwining of priestly and prophetic roles, foreshadowing continuity in the unity between spiritual and royal leadership.

verses.text: "Please inquire of the LORD for us, because Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon is making war against us. Perhaps the LORD will deal with us according to all His wondrous deeds, and he will make him withdraw from us."
verses.comment: Zedekiah’s appeal reflects a desperate hope for a miracle, referencing God’s past mighty interventions (see Exodus 14:30). This highlights human tendency to return to God in crisis and echoes Christ’s call to constant trust and faith, not just in hardship.

verses.text: Then Jeremiah answered them, "Thus you shall say to Zedekiah:
verses.comment: Jeremiah stands as the mouthpiece of God, reinforcing the concept of prophetic authority, a role expanded upon in the New Testament through apostolic succession (see Luke 10:16).

verses.text: "Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: 'Behold, I will turn back the weapons of war that are in your hands with which you are fighting against the king of Babylon and the Chaldeans who are besieging you outside the walls. I will gather them into the midst of this city.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty is declared over all nations—His plans are not frustrated by human defenses. The divine reversal here recalls later themes where Christ turns perceived defeat (the cross) into victory (see Acts 2:23–24).

verses.text: I myself will fight against you with outstretched hand and a strong arm, in anger, fury, and great wrath.
verses.comment: Where God once stretched out His hand for deliverance (Exodus 6:6), now He stretches it out for judgment. God’s justice and mercy are inseparable, making evident the need for total reliance upon Him—fulfilled ultimately in Christ as mediator (see 1 Timothy 2:5).

verses.text: I will strike down the inhabitants of this city, both man and beast; they shall die by a great pestilence.'
verses.comment: Divine judgment includes all of creation, emphasizing the consequences of collective sin. This warning prefigures the eschatological judgments in Revelation 6:8, where pestilence follows rejection of God.

verses.text: 'Afterward,' declares the LORD, 'I will give Zedekiah king of Judah, his servants, and the people in this city who survive the pestilence, the sword, and the famine, into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and into the hand of their enemies and into the hand of those who seek their lives. He will strike them down with the sword; he will not spare them or pity or have mercy.'
verses.comment: Judgment is certain. Notice the lack of mercy as a just response to persistent rebellion, which calls forward to Christian teaching about mercy and repentance through authentic, sacramental reconciliation.

verses.text: "And to this people you shall say: 'Thus says the LORD: Behold, I set before you the way of life and the way of death.
verses.comment: The language recalls Deuteronomy 30:19, urging the people to choose life. Christ repeats this call (John 14:6), demonstrating God continually invites free response, not coerced faith.

verses.text: Anyone who stays in this city will die by the sword, famine, and pestilence. But whoever goes out and surrenders to the Chaldeans who are besieging you will live and have his life as a prize of war.
verses.comment: Obedience, even if it means apparent defeat, leads to life. This anticipates Christ’s teaching that surrender of earthly attachments leads to true life (Matthew 10:39).

verses.text: For I have set my face against this city for harm and not for good, declares the LORD. It will be given into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he shall burn it with fire.'
verses.comment: The theme of God’s righteous judgment and the destructive consequences of sin is prominent. Yet, suffering and exile become means of purification, a foreshadowing of redemptive suffering in the New Testament (see Hebrews 12:6-11).

verses.text: "And to the house of the king of Judah say: 'Hear the word of the LORD:
verses.comment: God’s message is specific for the leaders, reminding them of their responsibility and the consequences of neglecting their role as shepherds of the people—a theme fulfilled in Christ, the Shepherd King (John 10:11).

verses.text: 'O house of David, thus says the LORD: "Render justice every morning and rescue the oppressed from the hand of the oppressor, lest my wrath go forth like fire and burn with none to quench it, because of the evil of your deeds."'
verses.comment: The call to justice is central in biblical revelation and is foundational to the one faith’s concern for charity and works of mercy. The phrase 'house of David' points to the messianic line—fulfilled in Christ (Matthew 1:1).

verses.text: "Behold, I am against you, O inhabitant of the valley, O rock of the plain," declares the LORD; "you who say, 'Who shall come down against us, or who shall enter our dwellings?'
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s overconfidence is rebuked. Trust in worldly security without humility before God is condemned, which aligns with New Testament teaching about self-reliance and pride (Luke 18:9-14).

verses.text: "I will punish you according to the fruit of your deeds, declares the LORD. I will kindle a fire in its forest, and it will consume all that is around it."
verses.comment: Both Old and New Testaments affirm God’s justice—reward and punishment based on deeds (see Revelation 20:12). This warns of final judgment, while also calling to a living, active faith expressed in works (see James 2:17).
